frameDefinitions: LUs in this frame denote a period of time in which an Enabled_action becomes possible.
An Agent pauses in the course of an Activity. '' 'The government froze settlement construction in 1992 to facilitate peace talks.'
In this frame a Part is part of a larger Whole comprised of parts that are ordered.
This frame has to do with the repetition (and especially the frequency of repetition) of an event.

An Assailant, a group of armed forces, surrounds the Victim, a military location and the people within it, in an attempt to cut the Victim off from the outside, with the goal of either forcing their surrender or weakening them so that an invasion would be successful.
Words in this frame name the different parts of the calendric cycle, both man-made and natural.
frameExamples: Allow a three-day <t>window</t> for delivery.  DNI
The government <t>froze</t> settlement construction in 1992 to facilitate peace talks.
I sat through the first interminable <t><fex name='Part'>act</fex></t>  of the play  .
China will have to face a high <t>frequency</t> of sand storms in the years to come.
Towards the end of the summer, a great English host <t>besieged</t> the Danish fort of Tempsford and took it, killing the last Danish king of East Anglia.
Jo's mother will visit on this coming <t>Tuesday</t>.
listRoleDefinitions: The action that becomes possible through the existence of the period of time.
A quantity or other characterization of the period of the time in which an <fen>Enabled_action</fen> is allowed.  In this frame, the duration may be exact or inexact.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the one who performs the <fen>Enabled_action</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> for which an <fen>Agent</fen> is pausing.
An <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an <fen>Agent</fen> pauses in the course of an <fen>Activity</fen>.
This is the number of the sequence of <fen>Part</fen>s.
A part of a larger <fen>Whole</fen>.
An undivided entity having all its <fen>Part</fen>s.
This role is used for any (bounded) <fen>Event</fen> whose frequency or iteration is described.
The extent to which the actually observed rate of occurrence of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> differs from the expected rate.
The <fen>Interval</fen> is a noun modified by the target word. The target word specifies the frequency of the <fen>Interval</fen> .
The <fen>Time_span</fen> is the length of time of the <fen>Interval</fen>. This role is incorporated by most of the lexical units in this frame.
The number of times per unit of real or scanning time that an <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> is encountered.
An entity which the implicit cognizer encounters with the specified frequency.
The frequency feature of the <fen>Event</fen> or <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is under discussion. All the lexical units in this frame incorporate this frame element.
The Time when the Event has a particular frequency.

The <fen>Assailant</fen> is a group of armed forces (or, metonymically, their commander or the organization they represent) that encircles, surrounds, or otherwise cuts off the Beseiged in an attempt to force surrender.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the fortification or geopolitical entity that is being attacked.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.
<fen>Relative_time</fen> is used for the word or words that locate the time with respect to an identifiable reference point.
<fen>Whole</fen> is used for the larger unit of which the target word names a part.
The calendric unit that is denoted. LUs in this frame all denote the <fen>Unit</fen>.
listRoleExamples: I sat through the <fex>first</fex> interminable <fex>act</fex> of the play .
I sat through the first interminable <fex>act</fex> of the play .
I sat through the first interminable <fex>act</fex> <fex>of the play</fex> .
The country has been struck by frequent <fex>economic crises</fex>.
The Crested Lark (Galerida cristata) is  <fex>very</fex> frequent from the coastal plain to the mountains.
You have to renew the license every <fex>year</fex> .
The state government spends its fiscal year 2006 budget of $23.4 billion at a rate <fex>of $742 per second</fex>.
It costs about US$2.50 to travel 200km (124 mi), but <fex>buses</fex> are infrequent and only one or two buses a day service most routes.
These exposures were likely to be intermittent <fex>in frequency</fex> occurring only when workers were participating in activities at these specific areas.
Jo's mother will visit <fex> this coming</fex> Tuesday.
Jo fled in the early morning <fex>of  Sunday December 15</fex>.
